title: R40110
content: With recent high energy prices, there is ongoing congressional interest in promoting greater use of alternatives to petroleum fuels, particularly biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel. Federal support for biofuels, including tax incentives and grant programs, has been significant but many incentives expired in 2011. The ongoing congressional debate over budget deficits makes extending these incentives less likely. The report outlines federal programs providing incentives for biofuels, with six incentives expiring in 2011 and two set to expire in 2012. Administered by EPA since 2005, the Energy Policy Act established a renewable fuel standard for automotive fuels, requiring the use of renewable fuels like ethanol and biodiesel. The Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) requires the use of renewable fuels in transportation fuel, including ethanol and biodiesel. Fuel suppliers must include increasing amounts of renewable fuel in the national transportation fuel supply, reaching 36 billion gallons by 2022. The RFS mandates the use of "advanced biofuels" with lower greenhouse gas emissions, with at least 21 billion gallons required to be advanced biofuel by 2022. EPA has issued rules for compliance and trading renewable fuel credits between suppliers. The EPA issued final rules for the expanded Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS2) in 2010, which included lifecycle analysis methods for categorizing fuels as advanced biofuels. The program is not a direct subsidy for biofuels plants but creates a guaranteed market to stimulate industry growth. Various tax credits and incentives for biofuels production expired at the end of 2011. Before the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010, biofuels incentives were set to expire, including tariffs on ethanol imports and tax credits for biodiesel, renewable diesel, and ethanol. These incentives were extended through 2011, but support for further extensions was limited. Administered by the IRS, the program was established in 2005 and modified in 2008. Gasoline suppliers who blend ethanol benefit from this program. Gasoline suppliers blending ethanol eligible for 45 cents per gallon tax credit until December 31, 2011. Administered by IRS, established in 1990, extended and expanded in subsequent acts. The small ethanol producer credit, valued at 10 cents per gallon, expired on December 31, 2011. It could be claimed on the first 15 million gallons produced by producers with capacity below 60 million gallons per year. Established in 2005, extended and amended by subsequent acts, it was administered by the IRS. For more information, refer to IRS Publication 510, Chapter 2: Fuel Tax Credits and Refunds. The biodiesel tax credit, established in 2005, was valued at $1.00 per gallon for biodiesel producers until December 31, 2011. It was extended retroactively to cover fuel produced in 2010 by P.L. 111-312. The credit applied to biodiesel made from virgin agricultural products or recycled fryer grease. Administered by the IRS, more information can be found in IRS Publication 510, Chapter 2. The small agri-biodiesel producer credit, established in 2005, is valued at 10 cents per gallon for agri-biodiesel producers with production capacity below 60 million gallons per year. It can be claimed on the first 15 million gallons of ethanol produced by a small producer in a given year until the end of 2011. The credit was extended by P.L. 111-312 to cover fuel produced in 2010. For more information, refer to IRS Publication 510. Producers of biomass-based diesel fuel (or producers of diesel/renewable biodiesel blends) with production capacity below 60 million gallons per year can claim a $1.00 per gallon tax credit until the end of 2011. Renewable diesel, produced through different processes, is ineligible for the biodiesel credits. The tax credit was expired at the end of 2009 and was extended by P.L. 111-312. The tax credit for producers of cellulosic biofuel, established in 2009, was extended by P.L. 111-312 to apply retroactively to fuel produced in 2010. Producers can claim $1.01 per gallon tax credit for cellulosic biofuel, with a reduced value of 46 cents per gallon for cellulosic ethanol. The credit applies to fuel produced after December 31, 2008. The tax credit for cellulosic biofuel producers, established in 2009, allows for a credit of $1.01 per gallon for cellulosic biofuel, with a reduced value of 46 cents per gallon for cellulosic ethanol. The credit applies to fuel produced after December 31, 2008 and is administered by the Internal Revenue Service. The accelerated depreciation for cellulosic biofuel plants was expanded to include all cellulosic biofuel plants, not just those using enzymatic processes. The provision applies to plants acquired after December 20, 2006, and placed in service before January 1, 2013. Plants with binding acquisition contracts before December 20, 2006, do not qualify. The program was established in 2005 and has been extended and expanded through various acts. For more information, refer to the Senate Finance Committee's summary of the House-Senate agreement on tax, trade, health, and other provisions from December 7, 2006. The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 provided a 30% credit for alternative fuel infrastructure installation, up to $30,000, including E85 infrastructure. Residential installations qualified for a $1,000 credit. Administered by the Rural Business-Cooperative Service, the program had annual funding of $74 million in FY2009 and $245 million in FY2010, with an additional $150 million annually authorized for FY2009-FY2012. The Rural Business-Cooperative Service administered a program with annual funding of $74 million in FY2009 and $245 million in FY2010 for loan guarantees. No discretionary funding was appropriated through FY2012. Established in 2008 by the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008, the program provided grants to biorefineries using renewable biomass to reduce fossil fuel use. Qualified applicants were existing biorefineries. Annual funding included $35 million in mandatory funding for FY2009, with an additional $15 million authorized annually for FY2009 through FY2012. Discretionary funding of $15 million was appropriated only in FY2010. The program was scheduled to terminate at the end of FY2012. For more information, visit the RBS website. Grants were provided to biorefineries using renewable biomass to reduce fossil fuel use under the Rural Business-Cooperative Service program. The program had mandatory funding of $55 million for FY2009, $55 million for FY2010, $85 million for FY2011, and $105 million for FY2012, with an additional $25 million authorized annually for FY2009-FY2012. The program was established in 2008 and was scheduled to terminate at the end of FY2012. For more information, visit the RBS website. The Rural Business-Cooperative Service program, established in 2008, provides payments to producers of advanced biofuels to support production expansion. Administered by the Commodity Credit Corporation, it authorizes the use of funds to purchase surplus sugar for bioenergy production. No appropriations have been made to date. For more information, visit the RBS website. The Biomass Crop Assistance Program (BCAP) was established in 2008 under the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act to provide matching payments for the collection, harvesting, storage, and transportation of biomass feedstock for biofuel production. Funding for BCAP was limited to $552 million in FY2010 and $432 million in FY2011, with further reductions in subsequent years. The program is administered by the Farm Service Agency and is scheduled to end in FY2012. The Biomass Crop Assistance Program (BCAP) provides matching payments for biomass delivery to biofuel facilities, with funding of up to $70 million annually. Administered by the Farm Service Agency, BCAP was established in 2008 and is set to end in FY2012. For more information, visit the FSA website. The Rural Energy for America Program (REAP) was established in 2001 to provide grants and loans for rural energy projects, including efficiency improvements and renewable energy projects. Administered by the National Institute of Food and Agriculture, REAP has mandatory funding of $20 million for FY2009, increasing to $40 million for FY2012. Additionally, discretionary funding of $35 million annually is authorized for FY2009-FY2012. The Biomass Research and Development Act of 2000 established grants for biomass research, development, and demonstration projects, including ethanol and biodiesel plants. The program was extended and funding expanded by subsequent legislation. Eligible applicants include a wide range of entities. Other programs within the Rural Business Cooperative Service could indirectly assist biofuels producers. For more information, visit http://www.brdisolutions.com/default.aspx. The Biomass Research and Development Act of 2000 established grants for biomass research, development, and demonstration projects, including ethanol and biodiesel plants. The program provides funds for cooperative biomass research and development for the production of fuels, electric power, chemicals, and other products. Annual funding is approximately $200 million for the biomass program, with various statutes authorizing funding. Qualified applicants vary depending on program goals each year. For more information, visit http://www.eere.energy.gov/biomass/. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 authorizes loan guarantees for biofuels plants using cellulosic material, municipal waste, or sugar cane. Administered by the DOE, it had $5.4 million for administrative expenses in FY2008 and $51 billion in loan guarantees for energy projects. No further appropriations were made in FY2010-FY2012. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 authorizes DOE to provide loan guarantees for energy projects, including biofuels, to reduce air pollutant and greenhouse gas emissions. Private lending institutions can apply for loan guarantees for clean energy projects. The program was established in 2005 and has an annual funding of $1 billion, with no more than $100 million to be paid in any given year. No further appropriations were made in FY2010-FY2012. Established in 2005 by the Energy Policy Act of 2005, section 942 authorizes the DOE to provide incentive payments for cellulosic biofuels until U.S. production reaches 1 billion gallons or 2015. Administered by U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the program is open to U.S. cellulosic biofuel production facilities meeting requirements. Annual funding details are not specified. The Ethanol Imports and the Caribbean Basin Initiative (CBI) program, established in 1975, imposes a 2.5% ad valorem tariff and a $0.54 per gallon duty on ethanol imports into the United States until the end of 2011. Most ethanol from CBI countries can be imported duty-free. The program is administered by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and applies to fuel ethanol importers. Annual funding details are not specified. The Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975 (P.L. 94-163), amended by the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, requires automakers to meet Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards for passenger cars and light trucks. Manufacturers can earn credits for selling alternative fuel vehicles, but these credits are limited to a maximum fuel economy increase of 1.2 miles per gallon until model year 2014. Credits are phased out after 2014 and completely eliminated after 2019.
